Task

Class SimplyTaskList

  • java.lang.Object
    • Task.SimplyTaskList

  • public class SimplyTaskList
extends java.lang.Object
    It creates a list about tasks and task priorities with priority categories. 
            SimplyTaskList usage example:
 
        public static void main(String[] args) {
                SimplyTaskList taskList = new SimplyTaskList("myTasks");

                System.out.println("Number of tasks:" + taskList.size());
                System.out.println("##################################################");
                System.out.println("# Adding some task to the taskList               #");
                System.out.println("##################################################");

                System.out.println("\nGetting information about priority categories:");
                System.out.println(taskList.getCategoryInfo());
    At first we can fill in the task list using the addTask(String, Integer, String, String) method. It automatically sorts the tasks. 
    
                taskList.addTask(taskList.getPriorityCategories().getFirst(), 1, "An aimportant task             ", "JDI - Just Do It");
                taskList.addTask("C", 1, "Finish housework", "");
                taskList.addTask("C", 1, "Go to lunch", "");
                taskList.addTask("A", 1, "This is a More important task", "Do it previous");
                taskList.addTask("B", 1, "Writing a letter", "Asking information about logging, compiling and complexity");
                taskList.addTask("A", 1, "This is the MOST important task", "Finish the documentation!!!");
                taskList.addTask("A", 3, "Do something useful", "");

                System.out.println();
                System.out.println("##################################################");
                System.out.println("# Getting my (ordered) task                      #");
                System.out.println("##################################################");
                System.out.println();


                System.out.println("P. category\tPriority\tTask name\t\t\t\tComment");

                for (int i = 0; i < taskList.size(); i++) {
                        System.out.print(taskList.getCategory(i) + "\t\t");
                        System.out.print(taskList.getPriority(i) + "\t\t");
                        System.out.print(taskList.getTaskName(i) + "\t\t");
                        System.out.println(taskList.getTaskComment(i));
                }
    When a task is ready, you can use the FinishTask(int) method. It removes the task from the task list and reorder the tasks. 
                    
                System.out.println();
                System.out.println("##################################################");
                System.out.println("# Finishing tasks                                #");
                System.out.println("##################################################");
                System.out.println();

                System.out.println("Finishing the first task");
                taskList.FinishTask(0);

                System.out.println("P. category\tPriority\tTask name\t\t\t\tComment");
                for (int i = 0; i < taskList.size(); i++) {
                        System.out.print(taskList.getCategory(i) + "\t\t");
                        System.out.print(taskList.getPriority(i) + "\t\t");
                        System.out.print(taskList.getTaskName(i) + "\t\t");
                        System.out.println(taskList.getTaskComment(i));
                }


                System.out.println("Finishing \"Do something useful\" task");
                taskList.FinishTask(1);

                System.out.println("P. category\tPriority\tTask name\t\t\t\tComment");
                for (int i = 0; i < taskList.size(); i++) {
                        System.out.print(taskList.getCategory(i) + "\t\t");
                        System.out.print(taskList.getPriority(i) + "\t\t");
                        System.out.print(taskList.getTaskName(i) + "\t\t");
                        System.out.println(taskList.getTaskComment(i));
                }
    To modify a task just use the setTask(int, String, int, String, String) method. With this you can modify the:
    • Task informations: task name, comment
    • Priority category
    • Priority 
    
                System.out.println();
                System.out.println("##################################################");
                System.out.println("# Modifying tasks                                #");
                System.out.println("##################################################");
                System.out.println();


                System.out.println("Modify information");
                taskList.setTask(0, "A", 1, "The MOST IMPORTANT        ", "At this time this is the most important task");

                System.out.println("P. category\tPriority\tTask name\t\t\t\tComment");
                for (int i = 0; i < taskList.size(); i++) {
                        System.out.print(taskList.getCategory(i) + "\t\t");
                        System.out.print(taskList.getPriority(i) + "\t\t");
                        System.out.print(taskList.getTaskName(i) + "\t\t");
                        System.out.println(taskList.getTaskComment(i));
                }


                System.out.println("Modify Priority and category");
                taskList.setTask(4, "A", 1, taskList.getTaskName(4), taskList.getTaskComment(4));

                System.out.println("P. category\tPriority\tTask name\t\t\t\tComment");
                for (int i = 0; i < taskList.size(); i++) {
                        System.out.print(taskList.getCategory(i) + "\t\t");
                        System.out.print(taskList.getPriority(i) + "\t\t");
                        System.out.print(taskList.getTaskName(i) + "\t\t");
                        System.out.println(taskList.getTaskComment(i));
                }
        }
    Version:
    0.3
    Author:
    Asuki

    • Constructor Detail

      • SimplyTaskList

        Parameters:

    • Method Detail

      • FinishTask

        public boolean FinishTask(int taskIndex)
        Removes the given name!'s task, puts in the finished task list and reorder the elements after the element in the same category. SimplyTaskList
        Parameters:
        taskIndex - The index of the task what we want to finish.
        Returns:
        true if the remove was successful and the active list had contained the task. Return false otherwise.

      • getTaskIndex

        public int getTaskIndex(java.lang.String taskName)
        Adds the index of the task in the active task list. Usage example: 
         
 SimplyTaskList getInfo = new SimplyTaskList("getTask");
        for (int i = 0; i < 6; i++) {
                getInfo.addTask("A", i + 1, "taskName" + i, "");
        }
        System.out.println(getInfo.getTaskIndex("taskName2"));
        Output: 2
        Parameters:
        taskName - The name what's index we search for.
        Returns:
        the index of the task if it is in the active task list and -1 otherwise.

      • getLastPriorityInCategory

        public int getLastPriorityInCategory(java.lang.String priorCat)
        Gives the last priority value of the given priority category. Usage example: 
         
 SimplyTaskList getInfo = new SimplyTaskList("getTask");
        for (int i = 0; i < 6; i++) {
                getInfo.addTask("A", i + 1, "taskName" + i, "");
        }
        System.out.println(getInfo.getLastIndexOfCategory("A"));
        System.out.println(getInfo.getLastIndexOfCategory("B"));
        Outputs: 5 -1
        Parameters:
        priorCat - The priority category what we want to find the last priority.
        Returns:
        The last element of the priority category.

      • isFinished

        public boolean isFinished(java.lang.String taskName)
        Checks if the task is finished.
        Parameters:
        taskName - The name of the task what we want to check if it is finished.
        Returns:
        true if the task is finished and false otherwise.

      • clearFinished

        public void clearFinished()
        Removes the element of the finished list.

      • getFinishedTaskNames

        public java.util.LinkedList<java.lang.String> getFinishedTaskNames()
        It gives the names of the finished tasks. Usage example: 
         
 SimplyTaskList getInfo = new SimplyTaskList("getTask");
        for (int i = 0; i < 6; i++) {
                getInfo.addTask("A", i + 1, "taskName" + i, "");
        }
        
        getInfo.FinishTask(2);
        getInfo.FinishTask(4);
        getInfo.FinishTask(0);
        
        for (String tasks : getInfo.getFinishedTaskNames()) {
                System.out.println(tasks);
        }
        Outputs: taskName2 taskName5 taskName0
        Returns:
        the name of the tasks

      • addTask

        public boolean addTask(java.lang.String pcat,
                       java.lang.Integer prior,
                       java.lang.String task,
                       java.lang.String comment)
        Ads a new task into the list. The method orders by categories and priorities.

        You can read examples here: SimplyTaskList

        Parameters:
        pcat - The priority category of the task.
        prior - The priority of the task.
        task - The name of the task.
        comment - Some information about the task.
        Returns:
        true if adding was successful and false otherwise

      • getPrevCatIndex

        public java.lang.Integer getPrevCatIndex(java.lang.String cat)
        Gives the index of the previous category from the priorityCategories list. Usage example: 
         
 
 SimplyTaskList getInfo = new SimplyTaskList("getTask");
        for (int i = 0; i < 6; i++) {
                getInfo.addTask("A", i + 1, "taskName" + i, "");
        }
        System.out.print(getInfo.getPrevCatIndex("A"));
        getInfo.addTask("C", 1, "C task", "comment");
        System.out.print(getInfo.getPrevCatIndex("C"));
        Output: -1 2
        Parameters:
        cat - The category what's ancestor we search.
        Returns:
        The index of the previous category and -1 otherwise.

      • getNextCatIndex

        public int getNextCatIndex(java.lang.String cat)
        Gives the index of the next category used from the possible category list. Usage example: 
         
 
 SimplyTaskList getInfo = new SimplyTaskList("getTask");
        for (int i = 0; i < 6; i++) {
                getInfo.addTask("A", i + 1, "taskName" + i, "");
        }
        System.out.print(getInfo.getNextCatIndex("A"));
        getInfo.addTask("C", 1, "C task", "comment");
        System.out.print(getInfo.getNextCatIndex("A"));
        Output: -1 2
        Parameters:
        cat - The category what's next we search.
        Returns:
        The index of the next category and -1 otherwise.

                       java.lang.String pcat,
                       int prior,
                       java.lang.String newTaskName,
                       java.lang.String newComment)
        Modify a task with the given information.

        You can read examples here: SimplyTaskList

        Parameters:
        taskIndex - The index of the task what we want to modify.
        pcat - The new priority category.
        prior - The new priority.
        newTaskName - The new name of the task.
        newComment - The modified comment.
        Returns:
        True if the the modify was successful, false otherwise.
